comment._content: LN series was London, Nov 1906 to March 1908, and 9942 is very near the end, so the photo is after March 1908.

comment.author: 38583742@N02
comment._content: If you send the photo to prewarcar.com they may well be able to identify the vehicles !  I like the 2 ladies in aprons offering refreshments !

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/foxglove] No idea myself, but if you join the following group and submit your photo, there's sure to be someone who will know. www.flickr.com/groups/car_memories_guesses/

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: This is indeed Molls Gap - here is the very point at which they are standing! maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=molls+gap+kerry&hl=en&ll... The bus on the left carries a sign saying " Parknasilla Waterville Cahirciveen" so was probably normally used as a service bus. This however appears to be a group outing - possibly councillors? If you have ever climbed the road to Molls Gap from any direction you would know why those 2 ladies were so welcome since it is such a tiring climb!

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Early version of the Avoca Café!

comment.author: 47173307@N00
comment._content: beautiful

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
The Avoca shop that is to the right of where this photo was taken sell some lovely Australian style liquorice thats very, very nice. Think they have Raspberry and Apple ;)
Great shot from then and now, is that the gap of Dunloe in the backround to the left?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Those cottages on the other side of the valley are on the 1842 OS Map - they must have been very isolated! You can just make out the traces of the settlement on Google Maps

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: I count about 14 moustaches and maybe one beard.

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: You could wait all day for a bus ... then three arrive at once!  Nothing changes!!!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] link to Irish Independent This puts Windy Gap much closer to Glenbeigh on the Kerry Way. I am confident that our photo is not Windy Gap.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] It is Molls Gap - look at today's image maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=molls+gap+kerry&hl=en&ll... This is the junction maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=molls+gap+kerry&hl=en&hn... I know the place well - one of my drivers at Ulsterbus Tours drove over this road in thick fog telling the passengers "Well, if it wasn't for the thick fog, you would have spectacular views of the scenery and the Lakes of Killarney - they look particularly beautiful today" ! I don't think they brought the tea ladies with them - they would eventually create the Avoca shop perhaps?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Moll's Gap limerick A day out to Windy Moll's Gap's Just the thing for a bus full of chaps. Be wary, it's airy On the old Ring of Kerry - You'll find it on all the good maps.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The interweb seems to disagree whether it is pronounced "charaBANK" or "charaBANG". Vital information for limerick artistes.  Perhaps a ruling from high in Library Towers?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I thought we had established that it is pronounced Cherry Bounce!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 

Speaking as a former Coaching Manager at Ulsterbus in Belfast, I can say with the highest authority that they are pronounced charaBANG although spelt charabanc.

There can be no other expert witness m'lady. The prosti......prosecution rests its' case.....on the floor! 

Mind the gap!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I never knew that there was a "Windy Gap" in Kerry, as far as I am concerned the one and only real "Windy Gap" is in the Clare Hills just outside Limerick!!!  I am sure that gaps may be described as windy from time to time but this is the first time I've heard Molls Gap called the Windy without the Molls appellation!!

comment.author: 35831938@N06
comment._content: It is wonderful.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] "The one and only real "Windy Gap" ... the dip between Black Mountain and Divis, just west of Belfast, is "Barnageeha" (bearna gaoithe}, does that not count as a Windy Gap? It's Ireland - there are lots of windy gaps!

Windy Gap Hopestown Westmeath 
Windy Gap Currahaly Cork 
Windy Gap Rooska Cork 
Windy Gap Glenagross Clare 
Windy Gap Ballymakellett Louth 
The Windy Gap Farnanes Cork 
Windy Gap Dromore South Cork 
Wind Gap Ballynakilly Lower Kerry

"Windy Gap" ... the dip between Black Mountain and Divis, just west of Belfast, is "Barnageeha" (bearna gaoithe},

comment._content: Oyez! Oyez! Sombre pronouncement from the National Library of Ireland! It's charaBANG as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] says, but I'm sticking with Cherry Bounce as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] reminded us. Read Little Women at an impressionable age, and thus these contraptions and conveyances will ever to Cherry Bounces to me...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
This one now amended to Moll's Gap.

But Who is Moll? What is she?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Moll's Gap is named after Moll Kissane.
The Gap itself is named after a woman, Moll Kissane, who reputedly ran a shebeen (a hostelry of dubious reputation) in this area in the 1800s.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Thank you! Moll Kissane now added to our tags...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
